plants.name: Crocus vernus
plants.description: A hardy perennial bulbous plant known for its early blooming, often appearing through late winter snow. It features cup-shaped flowers in vibrant shades of purple, yellow, or white, heralding the coming spring in temperate regions.
plants.location: Temperate regions of Europe and North America
plants.funFact: Crocus flowers are among the earliest bloomers, sometimes flowering under snow, symbolizing hope and renewal.

plants.name: Camellia japonica
plants.description: An evergreen shrub or small tree valued for its large, glossy leaves and showy flowers. Camellias bloom from late autumn through early spring, adding vibrant red, pink, or white flowers to gardens in mild climates.
plants.location: Eastern Asia and cultivated worldwide in mild climates
plants.funFact: Camellia japonica flowers were treasured in East Asia as symbols of purity and longevity for centuries.

plants.name: Protea cynaroides
plants.description: A striking South African native with enormous flower heads characterized by spiky outer bracts and a dense center of small flowers. The King Protea blooms during the southern hemisphere summer and offers a bold spectacle in floral arrangements.
plants.funFact: The King Protea is South Africa's national flower and can live up to 100 years in the wild.

plants.name: Witch Hazel (Hamamelis virginiana)
plants.description: A deciduous shrub native to North America, witch hazel stands out by blooming in late fall to winter, often flowering when few other plants do, with fragrant yellow flowers featuring strap-like petals.
plants.funFact: Witch hazel's extract is widely used in skincare for its astringent and anti-inflammatory properties.
